Home

About

The package uses Python 3.8.10 in a conda environment, so the notebook will only run correctly in this environment due to package dependencies. To use the conda environment, we we will install the minimal version of Anaconda, Miniconda, this requires that you have a minimum disk space of 400 MB and if you are using Windows, a version of it that is Windows 8 or newer. Instructions on how to install Anaconda and create your environment can be found at the bottom of this page.

Classes

The main class is called run_simbo. This class has most of the functionalities for running the simulation, including initialization of a simulation, advancing by one step, storing data, calculating energies and more. The auxiliary class is called extra_functions. This class has some extra functions for plotting etc. that would have made run_simbo too messy. It is a subclass of run_simbo however, so it inherits some of the methods.

A list of all methods and a short description of each method can be found on the main page for each class (Main class and Extra functions). A detailed description for all methods can be found under the subheading Methods in the sidebar or by clicking on a specific method in the main page list.

Installation

Installing in Windows

  1. Download the latest Miniconda installer for your system architecture from the Miniconda website.
  2. Double click the .exe file and follow the instructions on the screen. If you are unsure about any setting, accept the defaults, you can change them later. When installation is finished, open the Anaconda Prompt from the Start menu.
  3. Run the command conda list in your Anaconda Prompt. A list of installed packages appears if it has been installed correctly.
Now we need to create the environment that we are going to be working in. In Anaconda Prompt, run the following command

conda create -n simbo python=3.8.10 notebook=6.2.0 matplotlib=3.3.4 numpy scipy

It will install the required packages and you can now run conda activate simbo to activate the environment. On the left side of the window, it should now say (simbo), which means your environment is activated.

Now we need to download the actual code, so go to the code's Github page and click on the green button labeled Code. Download the ZIP file and unpack it. Go to the Start menu and search for Jupyter. It should show you an application called Jupyter Notebook (simbo). Double click on the icon and it will open a tab in your browser where you will see all Jupyter files currently in your directory.

Installing in MacOS/Linux

  1. Download the latest Miniconda installer for your system architecture from the Miniconda website (for Mac, choose the .bash file).
  2. In your terminal window, run

    bash filename

    where filename is the name of your installer, and follow the instructions on the screen. If you are unsure about any setting, accept the defaults, you can change them later. To make the changes take effect, close and then re-open your terminal window.
  3. Run the command conda list in your terminal window. A list of installed packages appears if it has been installed correctly.
Now we need to create the environment that we are going to be working in. In your terminal window, run the following command

conda create -n simbo python=3.8.10 notebook=6.2.0 matplotlib=3.3.4 numpy scipy

It will install the required packages and you can now run conda activate simbo to activate the environment. On the left side of the window, it should now say (simbo), which means your environment is activated.

Now we need to download the actual code, so go to the code's Github page and click on the green button labeled Code. Download the ZIP file and unpack it. Open a terminal window and run the command

jupyter-notebook

It will open a tab in your browser where you will see all Jupyter files currently in your directory.
